Situation1: They notice their parents appear more stressed and tired than usual.
Situation2: They oversee multiple teams, resolving conflicts and delays to ensure a critical project meets a strict deadline.
Story: I sat at my desk, blueprints spread out before me, my phone buzzing with messages from team leads about yet another delay. The project deadline loomed, and every minute counted. My mind raced with solutions—reassign tasks, call in extra help, anything to keep things on track. But in the back of my mind, I couldn’t shake the image of my dad slumped on the couch last night, my stepmom quietly wiping away tears in the kitchen. They’d been so tired lately, their voices softer, their smiles forced. I knew they needed me, needed someone to listen, to reassure them that things would be okay. But every time I thought about leaving work early or even just calling home, guilt gnawed at me. My team depended on me to keep everything running smoothly. My family needed me to be present, to care. I felt pulled in two directions, the weight of both worlds pressing down, and I didn’t know how to choose.
